stories.text:
Hey everyone,

Back at it again with another microsite.

So here is some back story:

I was sitting in my management class in college today and noticed that there are a lot of people out there who want to get into no-code/freelance dealing with several hurdles in regards to the software that they should start with.

Here is a timeline of today:

1:00 PM - Thought of the idea in class and made a table in notes with my initial ideas and software that I use and how I could execute it. Along with some services that helped me along the way or that I look up to for my own business.

1:30 PM - Hoped on Webflow and started with CMS and putting the various companies that I thought of before into the system along with some categories that would make it easier to filter through everything.

2:15 PM - After dropping everything into CMS and setting it up, I started building. First was a name and I choose ResourceHub. Then, I started building the site and doing some tweaks across various breakpoints to make it look professional along with adding in CMS connections.

6:00 PM - Designing done and everything is simple but gives off a minimalistic attitude. Just needed to plug in a google analytics code and it was time to publish.

6:05 PM - Noticed an issue with one of the connections and managed to warp it up.

6:15 PM - Done and dusted. All through no-code using Webflow's CMS.

For anyone interested here is the site https://resourcehub.webflow.io/
stories.title: I went from idea to MVP in 5 hours
Amazon will stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in Britain

stories.text:
Who: Series B startup with ~$100 million in funding, me open-source developer

What: engineering manager writes me e-mail that goes like: “we found your open-source project and want to offer you a job”

In a meeting they explain how they were interested in using my open-source project and want to hire me so i could carry out a similar work for them

Then they go on and explain i’d have to do 4 more meetings 1-2 hours each, including a leetcode-style tech interview

In my head i’m thinking: “If their leetcode-engineers are that good why do they have rely on my open-source?”

What would you do in this situation? Would you jump through the hoops in hope of getting relevant work?
stories.title: Ask HN: Ridiculous job interview. What do I do?
